message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has galactorrhea, which suggests excess prolactin production. Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist used to treat hyperprolactinemia, which is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms. Tamoxifene is used for breast cancer treatment and prevention, and haloperidol and carbidopa-levodopa are not related to the patient’s condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is not pregnant and the nipple discharge is guaiac negative, suggesting nonbloody discharge. Cabergoline is used to treat hyperprolactinemia, which can cause nonbloody nipple discharge. Tamoxifen is used to treat breast cancer, but that is not indicated in this patient. Haloperidol and Carbidopa-levodopa are not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nipple discharge without a palpable mass or other concerning findings is most commonly caused by elevated prolactin levels. Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist used to treat hyperprolactinemia and would be the most appropriate therapy. Tamoxifine is used to treat breast cancer, Haloperidol is an antipsychotic, and Carbidopa-levodopa is used to treat Parkinson’s disease, all of which are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s guaiac negative nipple discharge suggests that the most likely diagnosis is hyperprolactinemia. Of the options provided, Cabergoline is the most appropriate therapy as it is a dopamine receptor agonist that can inhibit prolactin secretion. Tamoxifene is used for breast cancer treatment and prevention, Haloperidol is an antipsychotic drug, and Carbidopa-levodopa is used to treat Parkinson's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A negative ß-HCG rules out pregnancy as the cause of nipple discharge. The negative guaiac test rules out bleeding as the cause of the discharge. The most likely cause in a non-pregnant patient is hyperprolactinemia, and cabergoline is a medication used to treat this condition. Tamoxifen is used to treat breast cancer, not nipple discharge. Haloperidol and carbidopa-levodopa are not indicated for this condition. Therefore, (C) cabergoline is the most appropriate therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest galactorrhea, which is usually caused by hyperprolactinemia. Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that reduces prolactin levels and is used to treat galactorrhea. Tamoxifen is used to treat breast cancer and may worsen galactorrhea. Haloperidol and carbidopa-levodopa are not used to treat galactorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest lactation due to hyperprolactinemia, and Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist used to treat hyperprolactinemia. Tamoxifine is used to treat breast cancer and has no benefit in lactation. Haloperidol and Carbidopa-levodopa are neuroleptic and anti-Parkinson drugs respectively and are not appropriate for lactation symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of galactorrhea, which can be caused by increased levels of prolactin. Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that can decrease prolactin secretion and is commonly used to treat galactorrhea. Tamoxifen is used to treat breast cancer and not galactorrhea. Haloperidol is an antipsychotic and not typically used to treat galactorrhea. Carbidopa-levodopa is used to treat symptoms of Parkinson's disease and is not indicated for galactorrhea.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperprolactinemia, which can cause both galactorrhea and amenorrhea. Cabergoline is a medication commonly used to treat hyperprolactinemia. Tamoxifene is primarily used in breast cancer treatment, and haloperidol and carbidopa-levodopa are not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest galactorrhea, which can be caused by hyperprolactinemia. Cabergoline is a dopamine receptor agonist that can reduce prolactin levels and treat galactorrhea. Tamoxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator and is not appropriate for this patient. Haloperidol is an antipsychotic that can also reduce prolactin levels, but it has significant side effects. Carbidopa-levodopa is a medication used to treat Parkinson's disease and is not appropriate for this patient.
